terms.definition: Standard Operating Procedure - a documented step-by-step process that outlines how to perform routine tasks consistently and safely
Good Manufacturing Practices - a system of guidelines and regulations that ensure products are consistently produced and controlled according to quality standards
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents over time, ensuring teams always work with the most current version
Detailed documentation that tracks all aspects of a specific production batch, including materials used, processes followed, and quality control results
Documentation that is properly organized, complete, and accessible for regulatory inspections or compliance reviews
A system where all documents and information are stored in a single, accessible location rather than scattered across multiple systems
The ability for multiple users to work on and access documents simultaneously with instant updates visible to all participants
Software and services that run on remote servers accessible via the internet rather than on local computers
Food and Drug Administration - the U.S. federal agency responsible for regulating cosmetics, food, drugs, and other consumer products
An international standard that provides guidelines for Good Manufacturing Practices specifically for cosmetic products
The process of locating and accessing specific documents or information from a documentation system
The systematic monitoring and documentation of adherence to regulatory requirements and industry standards
The coordination and optimization of business processes and document flows to improve efficiency and reduce errors
The ability to track and document the history, location, and application of products or processes throughout the manufacturing cycle
System-generated notifications that inform users of important updates, changes, or required actions without manual intervention
